metadata.source_file: Offshore Diver Medic - Full Course Theory.xml

assessment.instruction: Time: 15 minutes Task: Perform male urinary catheterization Performance Objective: As an IMCA DMT perform this activity with a basic understanding of theory and practice principles, using RMA from a Company Medical Advisor. Use your helpful hints to ensure your equipment preparation is correct. Ensure you maintain ANTT during urinary catheter insertion. Remember to decontaminate work surface , dispose of equipment correctly and monitor the patient urine out put.

related.description: Simulate radio medical advise and describe the wound
Identifies patient status (level of Consciousness)
Pain assessment. Uses PQRSTA initially and ongoing to determine when DCI symptoms disappear
Simulate radio medical advise and describe the DCI, Francis Smith and dive profile
Positioning of patient
Simulate radio medical advise and need for Chest drain insertion
Identifies patient status (level of Consciousness)
Simulate radio medical advise and describe the wound
Ongoing assessment and monitoring until evacuation
Manage injury using sound practice of ANTT
Ongoing assessment and monitoring until evacuation
Simulate radio medical advise
Simulate radio medical advise and describe the SAMPLE and Pain assessment
Ongoing assessment and monitoring until evacuation
N.O.I Has index of suspicion of cardiac problem due to general appearance of patient
Identifies patient status.
Simulate radio medical advise and describe the burn
Does 10 point burn assessment
Mentions all 5, Pain assessments for RMA analgesia.
Gets scoop, uses it correctly with head blocks to secure patient and transfer him to clinic
Mentions doing Vitals, Pain assessment, SAMPLE and full Head to Toe exam and ongoing assessment
Simulate radio medical advise
Sterile Gloves (mask and apron optional)
Urinary catheter and collection bag
5 or 10 mL syringe and sterile water
Sterile Dressing Pack including: • Kidney bowl • Sterile drape • Gauze swabs • Cotton wool balls • Dressing forceps • Yellow or red disposable bag
Open and prepare critical field using correct ANTT and disposable bag as an aid. Lay out drape, guaze, bowl with cotton wool
Peel open the urinary catheter at the attachment end and not the end that enters the penis. Leave on the side in the packet ready for when required.
Apply sterile gloves
Urinary Bag: Place bag with in arms reach, cap in place.
Check balloon on catheter-tip is intact by inflating it with air.
Tear a hole in the sterile drape and pull the penis gently through the hole
Draw up 10 ml sterile water or saline. Replace into package (micro-critcal field) or on the side of the critical field
Patient comfortable, clean and dry. Urine is draining into the bag. (30 - 40mls per hour is the normal flow)
Ask the patient to report any discomfort and observe closely for signs of distress.
Document: •Date, Time and Depth of Procedure. •Consent and Reason for catheterisation •Any problem experienced during the procedure. •Results of urine test
Remove urinary catheter from the outer cover using ANTT and place on the critical field
Withdraw the catheter gently (resistance can be felt when the balloon pulls against the bladder neck opening). Connect the urine collection bag if not already in place.
Ensure the urinary bag is CLOSED: Cover the patient and maintain dignity.

Remove all unnecessary items such as the inner cover of the urinary catheter, the drape and any other items. Stick the catheter to the inside thigh using adhesive tape to prevent any weight or pull on the penis and catheter.
If resistance is felt, gently increase the traction on the penis, apply steady pressure on the catheter and ask the patient to strain gently as if passing urine or to cough.
When urine begins to flow, Stop and attach the urinary bag using ANTT and then continue to advance the catheter almost to the Y connection.
Syringe and water: Gently inflate the balloon with the sterile water, according to the manufacturer’s direction (5-10ml).
Insert the catheter until urine flows.
